loans.name: Gliceria

texts.en: Gliceria G. is 56 years old and married. She supports her family by operating two business ventures: livestock and farming. She lives in Brgy. Cabutungan, Santander, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her livestock and farming businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). Gliceria is now borrowing PHP 27,000 to be used as additional capital for the business and to buy feeds and vitamins for the animals. This will be her 17th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 25,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Gliceria aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team: http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Aom's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is located Andoung Kien village in Takeo province. It has four members who have selected Mrs. Aom Y. who was born in 1957 as the group leader. All the members will use their portion of the loan in varied ways to support their businesses in this current year.

Mrs. Aom Y. is a juice seller in the local village where she is able to earn a large profit to support her family while her husband, Mr. Soeng Ban, is a recyclables seller. Since her husband’s business is going well, she wants to expand it. So Mrs. Aom Y. is seeking a loan to buy more recyclables; with the rest of the loan she will buy more juice. She is a mother of two children, one of whom is a chef while the other is a construction worker.

loans.use: To buy more recyclables

loans.name: Carolyn

texts.en: Carolyn P. is from the village of Parog-Parog, Solana, Cagayan. She is 41 years old. Carolyn is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Carolyn runs a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Carolyn has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,100 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. Carolyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carolyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. Carolyn is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be the seventh loan taken out by Carolyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Chhen

texts.en:
Mrs. S. and her family members are shown in the photo above. She is married with two young kids who attend primary school, while her husband helps be responsible for the family by growing crops on their own farmland.

To generate a daily income, S. built a store next to her house where she sells cooking ingredients, sweets (candies), cakes, and soft drinks to people who are nearby villagers or passers-by.

Since the farming season is coming, S. has requested a loan for her husband to use to plant a potato crop.

loans.use: To enable her husband to plant a potato crop

loans.name: Filomena

texts.en: Filomena C.'s main source of income comes from fattening pigs for sale. She is 50 years old, married and has five school-aged children. They are from the village of Parog-Parog, Solana, Cagayan. Filomena has been in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 4,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) when she sells one of her animals. Filomena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 18,000 PHP from ASKI. Filomena is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase medication for her livestock. This will be her sixth loan from ASKI. She plans to use additional revenue to financially support immediate members of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase medication for livestock

loans.name: Chom's Group

texts.en:
This village loan consists of nine people, located in Preak Thmey village, Kandal province. Mrs. Chom S. is 40 years old and is the village bank president having been selected by the members of this village loan.
   
Mrs. Chom S. is a flower seller in the market and she also sells sausage and balut (eggs with almost developed embryos, boiled and eaten in the shell) at her home while her husband, Mr. Phum Vannak, 42 years old, is a farmer who owns a plot of land that he uses to cultivate flowers. With their businesses, they are able to earn a small income to support their family. 

In order to support the flower selling, Mrs. Chom S. decided to ask for a loan to buy farm flowers and other flowers to enlarge her business activities. This couple has two children: one is a flower seller and another is a student in the local school.

loans.use: To buy farm flowers and other flowers to enlarge her business activities.

loans.name: Sum

texts.en:
Mrs. Sum T. is a villager in Daeum Pou village in Takeo province and she was born in 1972. She is a farmer who owns a 4-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice on to sell to support her family while her husband, Mr. Chuon Sum, is a maker of big pots who can earn some money to support his family. 

Mrs. Sum T.'s problem is that it is time to grow rice but she does not have enough rice seed. So to improve production, Mrs. Sum T. is asking for a loan to buy rice seed; with the rest of the loan she will buy fertilizer and gasoline. She is a mother of four children, one of whom is studying in school, while the others are farmers. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy rice seed

loans.name: Taufau

texts.en:
Taufau T. is 39 and married with 7 children. She owns a business planting and harvesting taro for sale.  Taufau has three years of experience in this business. Taufau needs a loan of 1,500 talas to purchase harvesting equipment such as wheelbarrows, shovels, rakes, baskets, and knives. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 350 talas or US $135 per week) to improve/expand the business.

Taufau joined SPBD in 2007. This is her third loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Taufau's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase harvesting equipment

loans.name: Bich's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Bich M., 54 years old, was selected as group leader by the four members of this loan group, located in Preaek Ta Nob village, Kandal province. With their loan, each member of this village bank hopes to increase his or her income to improve the living conditions of their family.

Mrs. Bich M. is a clothes seller in the local market who is able to earn a small income to support her family. She does not have enough money to expand this business so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more clothes to resell. Mrs. Bich M. is a widow with three children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory and the other two are attending the local village school.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to resell

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en: Catherine J. is 38 years old, married and supports her family by operating two business ventures: food vending and raising livestock. She lives in Palanas, Ginatilan, Cebu. Catherine has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2006 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and by her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). Catherine is now borrowing 16,000 PHP so that she can purchase raw materials for her food vending business. This will be her fifth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 14,000 PHP (which she paid off well within its term) was just another step on her journey toward economic freedom. Catherine aspires to improve her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials

loans.name: Julie

texts.en:
Julie O. is 39 and married with eight children. She owns a business planting and harvesting taro to sell.  Julie has three years of experience in this business. Julie needs a loan of 1,000 talas to purchase weed killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 350 talas or US $135 per week) to pay for her children's tuition fees.

In 2010, Julie joined SPBD. This is her first loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Julie's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase weed killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Nop

texts.en:
Mrs. Nop L. was born in 1944 and lives in Daeum Pou village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 3.2-hectare (8-acre) plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family. She is also a farm laborer.

Mrs. Nop L.’s problem is that it is time to grow rice but she does not have enough rice seed. So, to improve matters, she is asking for a loan to buy rice seed; with the rest of the loan she will buy fertilizer and hire a plowing machine to plow her field.

Mrs. Nop L. is a widow with three children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, another is a laborer, and the third is attending school.

loans.use: To buy rice seed for her farm

loans.name: Munkhtsetseg

texts.en: Munkhtsetseg is 51 years old and single with four children. She lives with one of her daughters, son-in-law and grandson in a suburb of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her daughter is a cadet in the Military Academy and son-in-law is a student at the University of Technical Science. The rest of her children are all married and live in their own homes. All her kids were teenagers when her husband left her for another woman and she was left to raise her four children on her own. Even though she was a single mother, she managed to raise her children to be healthy and send them all through college, a dream of most Mongolian parents. Munkhtsetseg is a hardworking woman with a strong will and she believes that a college diploma is the best legacy parents can give to their children. In 1994, she started a retail butcher business in the meat market in Ulaanbaatar city. She has gained valuable experience in previous years and has a loyal customer base.  During these years, she managed to buy a small house and mini-truck for her business. Sometimes her youngest daughter and son-in-law help with the business after school. With the loan that she is asking for, she is planning to increase her meat storage capacity and buy a new freezer.

loans.use: To buy a new freezer

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline L. is a 54-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures:  fish vending and bangus (a type of fish) fry businesses. She lives in Pasil, Brgy. Cayhagan, Sipalay City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1999 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, Evangeline is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 10,000 PHP. Evangeline is now borrowing 12,000 PHP to continue funding her business operations. This will be her 18th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 12,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Evangeline aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org.

loans.use: Fund Operations

loans.name: Kim

texts.en:
Mrs. Kim R. is a low-income citizen living in the province of Kompong Cham; she appears in the photograph above. Kim and her husband are farmers. In addition to their farm work, Kim also distills rice wine to sell.

Kim is taking out a loan to purchase a pump to irrigate her crops. With any remaining cash from the loan, she will buy piglets. She will raise the piglets with any leftover distilled wine.

loans.use: To purchase a pump to irrigate her crops

loans.name: Toem

texts.en:
Mrs. Toem S., who was born in 1974, lives in Daeum Pou village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 1.2-hectare (3-acre) plot of land that she uses to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Ratha Seang, is a grass seller in the local village and he is also a fisherman. Her husband is shown with her in the photo.

Mrs. Toem S.’s problem is that it is time to grow rice but she does not have enough rice seed. So, to improve matters, she is asking for a loan to buy rice seed.

Mrs. Toem S. is the mother of five children, one of whom is a laborer, while the others are attending school.

loans.use: To buy rice seed for her farm

loans.name: Razel

texts.en:
Razel B. is a married woman who lives in Jose Niquel Village in Barangay San Jose, a part of Sipalay City in Negros Occidental province, Visayas islands. She earns her living by buying and selling dried fish. Razel joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past eleven loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Razel has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 26,500 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 28,000 PHP, so lifting the family's standard of living.

This time, for her twelfth loan, Razel is borrowing 28,000 PHP, which she intends to use to purchase dried fish so that she can continue to save up for the future to buy a lot and home appliances. Razel B. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through its alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a dollar a day to achieving realities beyond their dreams. They are on a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon—a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more dried fish

loans.name: Malo

texts.en:
Malo F. is 58 and married with four children. She plants, harvests and sells taro. Malo has three years of experience in this business. 

In 2010 Malo joined and obtained her first loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Malo's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Malo needs a loan of 1000 talas to purchase harvesting equipment such as wheelbarrows, shovels, rakes, baskets, and knives. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $155 per week) to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase harvesting equipment

loans.name: Dominga

texts.en:
Dominga A. is from the village of Parog Parog, Solana, Cagayan. She is 50 years old. Dominga is married and has six adult children. To make a living, Dominga owns & operates a business raising pigs to fatten and sell. Dominga has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,200 PHP whenever she sells a pig.

Dominga joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dominga has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from ASKI. Dominga is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase pig feed & other supplies. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Dominga from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed & other supplies

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en: Mercedes L.'s main source of income comes from raising pigs for breeding. She is 43 years old, married and has two grown-up children. She is from the village of Parog Parog, Solana, Cagayan. Mercedes has been in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,200 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2005, Mercedes joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Mercedes has successfully repaid a previous loan of 29,000 PHP from ASKI. She is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase medication for her livestock. This will be her seventh loan from ASKI. She plans to use additional revenue to make improvements to her house. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase medication for her livestock

loans.name: Nget

texts.en:
Mrs. Nget A. was born in 1983 and lives in Daeum Pou village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare (3.75-acre) plot of land that she uses to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Ret Noun, is a fisherman and he is also a farm laborer. Through those activities, this couple supports two children, both too young to work or study. Her husband is shown with her in the photo.

Mrs. Nget A.’s problem is that it is time to grow rice but she does not have rice seed. So, to improve matters, she is asking for a loan to buy rice seed; with the rest of the loan she plans to buy fertilizer and hire a plowing machine to plow her field.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and fertilizer and to hire a plowing machine to plow her field

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace V. is 33 years old, married and from the village of Parog Parog within the municipality of Solana, Cagayan province on the Luzon islands. To make a living, Grace raises pigs for breeding. Grace has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

Grace joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. Grace is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase piglets to raise and sell in the future. She plans to use all additional revenue generated from the business to support immediate members of her family.

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Yar

texts.en: Mrs. Yar E. is a 33-year-old resident of Kompong Cham Province, where the territory is good for farming. Yar E. has a life partner in her husband, who appears in the photograph. This couple earns a living as crop cultivators, and they have two children who are dependent on their revenue. Yar E. is requesting her loan to hire a laborer who owns a machine to plow her farmland. She will then buy fertilizer and seed for planting.

loans.use: To hire a laborer who owns a machine to plow her farmland.

loans.name: Ros

texts.en:
Mrs. Ros L., who lives in Daeum Pou village in Takeo province, was born in 1967. She is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare (3.75-acre) plot of land that she uses to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. Moreover, she is also a farm laborer. She is widow with two children who are both seamstresses in a garment factory.

Mrs. Ros L. has a problem because it is time to grow rice but she does not have rice seed. So, to improve matters, she is applying for a loan to buy rice seed; with the rest of the loan she plans to buy fertilizer and hire a farm laborer and a plowing machine to plow her field.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and fertilizer and to hire a laborer and a plowing machine to plow her field

loans.name: Liezel

texts.en:
Liezel O., from the village of Parog Parog, Solana, Cagayan, is 27 years old, married, and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, Liezel owns and operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. Engaged in her business for over three years, she earns approximately 4500 PHP when she sells one of her raised animals.

Liezel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 12000 PHP from ASKI, she is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be Liezel's fifth loan from ASKI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Sina

texts.en:
Sina I. is 43 and married with 5 children. She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Sina has one year of experience in this business. She needs a loan of 1700 talas to purchase fertilizers such as manure.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 600 talas or US $235 per week) to improve/expand the business.

Sina joined SPBD. This is her 4th loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Sina's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Vann's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Vann T. is a 25-year-old married woman who was selected as the leader of this group by its four members. The members are located in Samraong K'aer village, Kandal province, and they will each use their part of the loan to support their different purpose.

Mrs. Vann T. and her husband, Mr. So TH., are fishermen in the local village and are able to earn a small income to support their family. They have two children, aged 3 and 7. Their family house does not have electricity, so Vann TH. decided to ask for a loan to buy a battery to light the house at night.

loans.use: To buy a battery to light her house at night

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert T. is from the village of Ubong, Solana, Cagayan. He is 23 years old. Robert is married and has one infant child. To make a living, Robert owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Robert has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

Robert joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Robert has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from ASKI. Robert is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Robert from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: María Eva

texts.es: María Eva R. D. C. D. 47 años D. edad, resiD. en el departamento D. Usulután, vive junto a su esposo y tres hijos menores D. edad, los cuales son unos jóvenes muy estudiosos y responsables. María se dedica a la venta D. medicina natural, la cual comercializa desD. hace 14 años,  así mismo con el fin D. obtener algunas ganancias extras, ella se dedica a vender productos D. belleza como: perfumes, maquillaje, cremas para el cuerpo y el cabello. María es una mujer muy trabajadora, la cual trabaja D. forma ambulante para poder comercializar sus productos. Ella solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda invertir más en su negocio aumentando su inventario, ya que es vital para María poder contribuir con los gastos del hogar y D. esta forma poder solventar todos los gastos del hogar.
texts.en:
María Eva R. D. C., 47, lives in Usulután Department with her husband and three minor children, who are studious and responsible young people. María has sold natural remedies for the last 14 years. In order to earn extra income she also sells cosmetics like: perfumes, makeup, body creams and hair creams. María is a very hard working woman who works in an itinerant manner to sell her products. She is asking for funding to buy more stock items because it’s vital for María to be able to contribute towards meeting household expenses and this is a way to do so.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cosmetics and natural remedies.

loans.name: Pov

texts.en: Mrs. C., 36 years old, owns a small wooden house and a grocery shop, where she sells many items, including cooking ingredients, sweets, and soft drinks. C. retails her inventory to people who are passers-by and also to her neighbors living near her house. She has been running a grocery store for a long time and earns an average of US$ 5 a day. Besides this, C. and her husband always take time to raise rice and pigs at their home. C. is taking out her loan to increase her inventory to meet the requirements of her customers. (Mrs. C.’s husband is in the photo above.)

loans.use: To increase her inventory to meet requirements of her customers

loans.name: Juana Virginia

texts.es: Juana Virginia O. R. de 55 años de edad, es una señora muy trabajadora y responsable, la cual se esfuerza a diario para poder contar con su sustento y todo lo necesario para su hogar. Ella es una persona soltera quien tampoco tiene hijos, reside en Puerto el Triunfo, ubicado en el departamento de Usulután. Juana se dedica a la venta de pescado, así mismo elabora tortillas, las cuales comercializa en su casa de habitación. Juana es una persona muy conocida en la zona ya que cuenta con muchos años de dedicarse a este oficio. Ella solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad de maíz, así mismo comprar tambos de gas propano para contar con una pequeña provisión de estos, ya que en muchas ocasiones este escasea durante el año, de esta misma forma ella comprará mayor cantidad de pescado el cual también comercializa en su casa de habitación.
texts.en:
Juana Virginia O. R., 55, is a very hardworking, responsible woman who struggles daily to earn support for her household. She is single and doesn’t have any children. She lives in Puerto El Triunfo in Usulután Department. Juana sells fish but also makes tortillas that she sells from home. She is very well known in the area because she’s been in this line of work for many years. She is asking for funds to buy a larger amount of corn as well as tanks of propane gas in order to have a small supply of them because often it becomes scarce during the year. She also wants to buy larger amounts of fish which she also sells from home.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy corn at wholesale and to buy propane gas.

location.town: Puerto el Triunfo, departamento de Usulután

loans.name: Lupe

texts.en:
Lupe N. is 40 and married with two children. She owns a business venture, planting and harvesting taro for sale.  Lupe has many years of experience in this business. Lupe needs a loan of 2000 talas to purchase harvesting equipment such as wheelbarrows, shovels, rakes, baskets, and knives. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 650 talas or US$ 251 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2008, Lupe joined SPBD. This is her 3rd loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Lupe's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: to purchase harvesting equipment such as wheelbarrows, shovels, rakes, baskets, and knives

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora G. is from the village of Ubong, Solana, Cagayan. She is 39 years old. Nora is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Nora owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. Nora has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

Nora joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. Nora is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Nora from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Yanira Marisol

texts.es: Yanira Marisol G. de 39 años de edad, reside en el departamento de Usulután, el cual se encuentra en el oriente del país. Ella vive junto a sus cinco hijos menores de edad, los cuales se dedican a estudiar. Como toda madre soltera Yanira debe trabajar muy duro por poder sacar adelante a su familia, es por ello que se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza como: cremas para el cuerpo y el cabello, perfumes, maquillaje y otros más, este producto lo vende en su casa de habitación y así mismo sale a comercializarlo con vecinos y amigos. Ella también comercializa ropa para niños, hombres y mujeres, esta  la vende de forma ambulante por diferentes colonias y cantones del departamento de Usulután, ella cuenta con muchos clientes fijos ya que ofrece muy buenos precios. Yanira solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda contar con el dinero necesario para invertir en su negocio comprando productos de belleza y así mismo ropa en diferentes estilos, tallas y colores de forma que pueda abarcar mayor cantidad de clientes. El mayor deseo de Yanira es el de mejorar sus ganancias y de esta forma brindarle una vida mejor a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Yanira Marisol G., 39, lives in Usulután Department, located in the east of the country. She lives with her five minor children who are students. Like every single mother Yanira must work very hard to raise her family. For this reason she is a beauty supplies merchant, such things as: body creams and hair creams, perfumes, makeup and others. She sells from home and also goes out to sell directly to neighbors and friends. She also sells children, women and men’s clothing in an itinerant way throughout the various neighborhoods of Usulután Department. She has many regular customers because her prices are very good. Yanira is asking for funds to buy beauty products and clothes of different styles, sizes and colors so she can attract a wider variety of customers. Yanira’s greatest wish is to improve profits so that she can offer her children a better life.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothes and cosmetics to sell.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia R. is from the village of Ubong, Solana, Cagayan. She is 51 years old. Lydia is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Lydia owns & operates a business selling fish and vegetables in the local community. Lydia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

Lydia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lydia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from ASKI. Lydia is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Lydia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Savali

texts.en:
Savali S. is 36 and married with five children. She owns a business selling BBQ (sausages, chicken, and plantains). Savali has three years of experience in this business. Savali needs a loan of 1,500 talas to buy BBQ meat, ketchup, plastic plates & utensils, and coal. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $195 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2008, Savali joined SPBD. This is her fourth loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Savali's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To buy BBQ meat, ketchup, plastic plates & utensils, and coal

loans.name: Rosadel

texts.en:
Rosadel E. is 61-years old, married and supports her family by operating two business ventures, a general store and e-loading (the sale of pre-paid mobile phone credits). She lives in Phase 3 of Barangay Canturay, a part of Sipalay City, Negros Occidental province in the Vasayas islands. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2001 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and e-loading business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 3500 PHP.

Rosadel is now borrowing 15,000 PHP so that she can purchase more stock for her general store. This will be her eighth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 15,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Rosadel aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through its alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a dollar a day to achieving realities beyond their dreams. They are on a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon—a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock for her store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Chom's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Chom S. is a 33-year-old woman married to Mr. Phat Sophea, who is 32 years old and works as a construction worker. They have a child, who just a year old. Chom is the leader of a group loan who was selected by its four members located in Trapeang Chak village, Kandal province.

Chom earns a living as a seamstress in a garment factory. With both of their jobs they are able to earn a small income that supports their family. In order to increase their income and improve the family’s standard of living, Chom decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. With this new business they hope that their family’s life will improve.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: José Efraín

texts.es: José Efraín P. R. de 40 años de edad, es un hombre muy dedicado a su familia, por quien trabajada a diario para brindarle todo lo mejor. Él vive junto a su esposa la cual se dedica a los quehaceres del hogar, y así mismo junto a sus dos hijos menores de edad, ellos viven junto a su padre en Puerto el Triunfo, muy cerca de las playas de Usulután. José trabaja comercializando camarones frescos y secos, los cuales vende de forma ambulante, debido a que ofrece precios muy aceptables, cuenta con muy buenas ganancias así mismo por lo años que tiene de dedicarse a este oficio, es muy conocido, lo cual le permite contar con varios clientes fijos, los cuales le compran con frecuencia los camarones. José solicita un préstamo con el deseo de mejorar su negocio y así invertir en el, comprando una mayor cantidad de camarones tanto secos como frescos, de forma que pueda abarcar más a ambos mercados y así de esta manera poder ganar más. Esto llena de mucha ilusión a José ya que así podrá mejorar la estabilidad de su hogar.
texts.en:
José Efraín P. R. is a 40 year old gentleman who is very dedicated to his family and works every day to provide them the best. He lives with his wife, who takes charge of the household duties, and together they have two young children. In addition, they live with his father in Puerto El Triunfo which is near the beaches of Usulután.

José sells fresh and dried shrimp as a street vendor. Since he offers very affordable prices, José has been able to generate good earnings during the many years he has been in business. He is well-known and has many established customers who buy shrimp from him on a frequent basis. José is requesting a loan because he wants to improve his business and invest in it. He will buy a large quantity of fresh and dried shrimp so that he can sell more at both of the local markets and increase his earnings. José is filled with great aspirations of achieving improvement in his household stability.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fresh & dried shrimp to sell

location.town: Puerto el Triunfo, departamento de Usulután

loans.name: Flordelita

texts.en:
Flordelita P. is from the village of Ubong, Solana, Cagayan. She is 34 years old. Flordelita is married and has 3 very young children. To make a living, Flordelita owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Flordelita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP when she sells her raised pig.

Flordelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Flordelita is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Flordelita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Mrs. Chheun Sophaon Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Born in 1984, Mrs. Chheun S. and her husband, Mr. Hor Yeu, are farmers who own a one-hectare plot of land where they grow rice to sell to support their family. She is also a knitter. They have two children who are too young to work or study.

Chheun is the village’s bank president who was selected by nine people who live in Rumlok village in Takeo province. With this group loan they will each use their portions of the loan in varied ways to support their families. Chheun has a problem in that her rice field is infertile. To improve her production, she will use her loan to buy fertilizer, pesticides and gasoline.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticides and gasoline

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel M. is from the village of Barangay 1, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 28 years old. Maricel is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Maricel owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks & other delicacies like baked "siopao" and sugar-coated bananas in the local community. Maricel has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Maricel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maricel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Maricel is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Maricel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Sonia Isabel

texts.es: Sonia Isabel P. O. de 46 años de edad, reside en el departamento de Usulután, ubicado al oriente del país, ella es una señora muy responsable y trabajadora  la  cual cuenta con muy buenos valores, razón por la que es muy respetada y querida. Vive junto a su esposo quien trabaja como comerciante, manera a través de la cual aporta a su hogar, así mismo vive junto a dos hijos menores  de edad. Sonia brinda el apoyo financiero necesario a su esposo, a través de una tienda de productos perecederos y de primera necesidad, la cual les permite contar con una vida estable, en la cual pueden suplir  las necesidades de sus hijos con muchos esfuerzos de todo lo necesario. Sonia solicita un préstamo a través del cual le pueda brindar la ayuda necesario a su esposo, surtiendo más la tienda con productos como: medicinas, bebidas, pan, golosinas y otros más, así de esta forma ella espera obtener mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Sonia Isabel P. O. is 46 years old. She lives in the departament of Usulután, located in the eastern region of the country, She is a very responsible and hard working woman who has very good values. For this reason, she is very respected and well liked. She lives with her husband who works as a merchant, which is how he supports the family. She also lives with her two minor children. Sonia helps her husband financially through a perishable products and basic necessities store. This allows them to have a stable life and, with a lot of hard work, provide them with every thing they need. Sonia is asking for a loan with which she can offer her husband the help he needs, diversifying her store more with products such as: medicine, beverages, bread, snacks and others. In this way, she hopes to obtain more profit.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy products of  basic necessity.

loans.name: Feliuai

texts.en:
Feliuai A. is 42 and married with no children. She owns a business venture, planting and harvesting taro for sale.  Feliuai has twp years of experience in this business. Feliuai needs a loan of 1200 talas to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US$ 195 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Feliuai joined SPBD. This is her 2nd loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Feliuai's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Seam

texts.en: Mrs. Seam Y., 43, is a local rice farmer. She always stays at home to do her daily chores as well. Another income comes from her husband who sells ice-cream out of his motorcycle. This couple has eight children, five of whom are already married and have started new homes, and the other three are single and live at home. There is a piece of neighbor’s farmland in good location for cultivating. Seam Y. is hoping to be the owner of this land but she does not have enough cash to buy it. Thus, she is asking for assistance to buy this farmland, on which she will plant crops for extra income. Note: Mrs. Seam Y. was not available that day, so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: to buy a piece of  farmland on which she will plant crops for extra income

loans.name: Lelita

texts.en:
Lelita G. is from the village of Ubong, Solana, Cagayan. She is 48 years old. Lelita is married and has 7 children. To make a living, Lelita owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Lelita has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Lelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lelita is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Lelita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rosa Del Carmen

texts.es: Rosa Del Carmen E. de 45 años de edad, reside en la ciudad de Soyapango, una de las ciudades con mayor comercio del país, esta se encuentra ubicada en el departamento de San Salvador, en donde Rosa vive junto a su esposo, dos sobrinos y una hija, todos menores de edad. Rosa es una señora muy dedicada a su hogar, la cual se dedica a la elaboración de tamales, los cuales son hechos con masa de maíz, los cuales se rellenan de carne de pollo y algunas verduras y posteriormente se envuelven en hojas de huerta de guineo, estos los comercializa en su casa de habitación y así mismo los vende de forma ambulantes en colonias cercanas a su lugar de vivienda. De esta misma forma Rosa comercializa cocos, los cuales vende en su casa, los cuales su esposo le ayuda a vender. Ella solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda contar con el dinero necesario para comprar mayor cantidad de materia prima para la elaboración de tamales, los cuales son un platillo típico de este país, y así mismo comprar cocos por mayor y de esta forma obtener mayores ganancias, las cuales sean de mucho beneficio para ella y su familia.
texts.en:
Rosa Del Carmen E. is 45 years old. She lives in the city of Soyapango, one of the most commercial cities in the country. It is located in the departament of San Salvador, where Rosa lives with her husband, two nephews and a daughter, all minor children. Rosa is a woman who is very dedicated to her home. She makes tamales there from corn meal. They are filled with chicken and some vegetables and wrapped in banana leaves. She sells them from her house and she also sells them as a streetr vendor in the neighborhoods near her house. Rosa also sells coconuts in the same way in her house, and her husband helps her. She is asking for a loan to be able to have enough money to buy a larger quantity of ingredients to make the tamales, a traditional food in this country. It is also to buy coconuts wholesale and in this way obtain more profits, which is of great benefit to her and her family.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients for tamales and coconuts to sell.

loans.name: Uch Socheat's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Uch S. is a 30-year-old married woman with two children. One is attending the local school while another one, age five, is not in school yet. Her husband, Mr. Borin Pov, is 31 years old and a motorbike taxi driver. Uch was selected to be the village’s bank president by its twenty-one members who are located in Ta Reab Doun Sa village, Kandal province.

Uch earns a living by selling sweets, balut eggs, and both alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks. Borin also helps in his wife’s business activities. With these occupations, they are able to make a monthly profit and raise the family’s standard of living.

In order to increase their income and improve the family’s life, Uch will use her portion of the loan from AMK to buy more drinks, balut eggs and sweets to enlarge her business activities.

loans.use: To buy more drinks, balut eggs and sweets

loans.name: Mrs. Min Tha Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The eight people who make up this village bank loan have selected Mrs. Min T., who is 40, as the village bank president. The members are located in Rumlok village in Takeo province and they will each use their portion of the loan in varied ways to support their business in this current year.

Mrs. Min T. is a knitter at her home where she is able to earn some money to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Ret Ouch, is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare (3.75-acre) plot of land that he uses to cultivate rice to sell to support his family.

Mrs. Min T.’s current problem is that her husband’s field has infertile soil, has a lot of insects, and it is far away from the irrigation system. So, to improve production, she is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide, and gasoline for the water pump.

Mrs. Min T. is the mother of four children who are all attending school. They also help their parents’ businesses.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide, and gasoline for her husband's farm

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa T. is from the village of Andarayan South, Solana, Cagayan. She is 48 years old, married and has 2 adult-aged children. Marissa owns and operates a business selling  fish in the local community. Marissa has been engaged in her business for over 36 years and earns approximately 3.500 PHP a month from it.

In 2008, Marissa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marissa has successfully repaid a previous loan  from ASKI. She is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Marissa from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Aliyyah

texts.en:
Aliyyah S. is from the village of Barangay 4, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 21 years old, married and has 1 infant. Aliyyah owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling video compact discs in the local community. Aliyyah has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Aliyyah joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aliyyah has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to invest in expanding the business. Aliyyah is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Aliyyah from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital

loans.name: Mirna Yaneth

texts.es: Mirna Yaneth P. T. de 26 años de edad, es una madre soltera muy trabajadora y emprendedora, la cual vela por el bienestar de su pequeña hija de dos años de edad, junto a la cual vive en el municipio de Soyapango. Mirna posee su propio negocio en el cual comercializa carne de res y de pollo, así mismo chorizos, salchichas y otros derivados, desde hace 6 años que ella trabaja de esta manera, y por brindar un excelente servicio y calidad de sus productos, ella cuenta con muchos clientes los cuales le compran semanalmente sus productos. Mirna solicita un préstamo con la intención de poder comprar mayor cantidad de carne de res y así también chorizos, salchichas, chuletas y otros derivados más, lo que más desea Mirna es el poder mejorar sus ganancias, ya que ella espera brindarle una vida mejor a su pequeño hijo, el cual depende únicamente de ella para salir adelante y contar con todo lo necesario como estudios y vivienda.
texts.en:
Mirna Yaneth P. T. is 26 years old and a hard working enterprising single mother who works long hours for the well being of her two year old daughter. They live in the city of Soyapango. Mirna has a business where she sells beef and chicken, as well as sausages, franks, and other meat products. She’s been doing this for six years and has many customers who buy from her regularly each week, thanks to the excellent service she provides. She is asking for this loan in order to buy a large quantity of beef, chicken, sausages, franks, chops, and other meat products. What she desires the most is to increase her income so that she can give her young child a better life. She is her only means of support and her sole provider of a home, education and means to get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Meats

loans.name: Taulau

texts.en:
Taulau T. is 34 and married with 8 children. She owns a business venture, selling pancakes (fried flour pancakes flavored with lemon or coconut jam). Taulau has three years of experience in this business. Taulau needs a loan of 1500 talas to buy flour, flavorings, sugar, and plastic bags. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 350 talas or US $135 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Taulau joined SPBD.  This is her 2nd loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Taulau's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: to buy flour, flavorings, sugar, and plastic bags

loans.name: Walter Ivan

texts.es: Walter Ivan L. H. de 32 años de edad, reside en el municipio de Soyapango, lugar en el cual está ubicado su  negocio el cual es un cibercafé, en el que trabaja desde hace 10 años. Él vive junto a su madre quien se dedica a los quehaceres del hogar y la cual depende de Walter. En el negocio  no solamente brinda el servicio de internet sino también comercializa productos como: Cd’s, lapiceros, folders, paginas de papel bond, cuadernos y diferentes tipos de papelería, lo cual le permiten ampliar su negocio. Con el deseo de poder mejorar el cibercafé, Walter solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda contar con el dinero necesario para comprar accesorios para computadoras como: monitores, mouse, parlantes, audífonos, cámaras y otros más, esto con el deseo de poder  brindar un mejor servicio a sus clientes, así mismo Walter quiere invertir en papelería y así mismo para comprar una fotocopiadora, la cual es un muy buen negocio. Él es una persona que cuenta con muy buenas referencias personales, ya que es muy emprendedor y así mismo por contar con un enorme deseo para salir adelante.
texts.en:
Walter Ivan L. H., 32, lives in Soyapango which is where he has also had his Internet café for the last 10 years. He lives with his mother who is a housewife and who depends on Walter. The business isn’t just an Internet café, he also sells merchandise like: CDs, mechanical pencils, folders, sheets of bond paper, notebooks and various stationery items that allow him to expand his business. Wanting to improve his Internet café Walter is asking for funds to buy accessories for the computers like: monitors, mice, speakers, microphones, webcams, etc. in order to provide better customer service. He also wants to buy more stationery items and buy a photocopying machine, which is a very good business. He has very good personal references because he is very enterprising and has a strong will to succeed.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy PC accessories.

Mrs. S. Y. and her husband, Mr. Roem Phoeurn, are farmers who own a 1.5-hectare (3.75-acre) plot of land that they use to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. Their problem is that their field has infertile soil, but they do not have enough money to solve the problem. So, to improve production, Mrs. S. Y. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer.

Mrs. S. Y. is the mother of four children, two of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory, another does telephone repair, and the other is a laborer.

loans.name: Lun's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Lun P., a 37-year-old married woman, was selected as the village bank president by its twenty-two members who all live in Ta Reab Doun Sa village, Kandal province. With their loan, each member of this village bank hopes to increase his or her income to improve the living standard of his or her family. Some of the members are blocked in the photo.

Mrs. Lun P. and her husband, Mr. Doem Roeun, are able to earn a living from their farm. They rent some of the land that they use to cultivate cucumbers and bananas. In order to support this farm, Lun P. will use the loan to buy farm supplies to cultivate more bananas and cucumbers.

Beside being farmers, the couple are also fishermen in the local village, from which they are able to earn a small income to support their family. They have four children: two stay at home while the others attend the local school.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies to cultivate bananas and cucumbers

loans.name: Kerta Jaya Amerta Group

texts.en:
Ni Luh M. is a 54-year-old woman living in the town of Melaya - Bali.  Ni Luh M. is the group leader of a 10-member group loan offered by MUK.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Kerta Jaya Amerta (PK-10263).


Ni Luh M. is married and has 5 adult children.  To make a living, Ni Luh M. owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale.  Ni Luh M. has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 200,000 IDR a month from these activities.


In 2010, Ni Luh M. joined MUK to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Ni Luh M. is requesting for the first time a loan from MUK in the amount of 1,500,000 IDR which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.  This will be the 1st loan taken out by the borrower from MUK.  Ni Luh M. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.


About MUK:

The mission of Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) is to assist small businesses in Bali by providing training, business consultation and loans thereby helping the owners and their families improve their everyday lives.





Ni Luh M. 0 (0) merupakan 54 tahun wanita.  Dia (perempuan) tinggal di kota Melaya - Bali.  Ni Luh M. adalah pemimpin kelompok sebuah kelompok peminjam yang terdiri atas 10 anggota.  Meskipun setiap anggota kelompok menerima pinjaman perorangan, mereka semua bertanggung jawab untuk mengembalikan pinjaman rekan anggota kelompok mereka jika ada yang menunggak atau gagal membayar.  Nama resmi kelompok peminjam ini adalah Kerta Jaya Amerta (PK-10263).


Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari beternak babi untuk dijual.  Ni Luh M. sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 5 tahun.  Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, Ni Luh M. menghasilkan sekitar 200,000 IDR.  Dalam 2010, Ni Luh M. bergabung MUK untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan  -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis.  Ni Luh M. meminta pinjaman untuk pertama kalinya dari MUK.    Dia (perempuan) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 1,500,000 IDR.


Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 1st pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari MUK.


Tentang MUK:

Misi Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) adalah untuk membantu usaha kecil di Bali dengan memberikan perlatihan, konsultasi bisnis, dan pinjaman uang, dengan demikian membantu pemilik usaha dan keluarga mereka memperbaiki hidup sehari-hari.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Suy

texts.en:

Then, the people turn the metal into housing materials. He has another financial earner in his wife who works sewing clothes in a garment factory.  He has an elderly mother (pictured) who stays at home to manage the household and take care of his two children. 

Suy C. is concerned that he doesn’t have a suitable location to use to operate his service. He has dreamt of having a workshop for a long time but he has no money to build one. This is why Suy C. decided to pursue a loan, in order to build a workshop.

loans.name: Ana Francisca

texts.es: La Sra. P. M. es comerciante del mercado la estación, inicia a elaborar la comida a la 3:00 am posteriormente se traslada al mercado para realizar sus ventas y finaliza a las 9:00 am, la Sra. P. ha utilizado los créditos que CEPRODEL le ha otorgado para la compra al por mayor de los productos para la elaboración de comida donde obtiene mayor ganancia y así ha podido mejorar su nivel de vida, este negocio lo inicio en su vivienda con un capital de C$ 500.00 producto de aportes de sus hijos.
texts.en:
Mrs. Palacion M. is a merchant in the La Estación Market. She starts to make food at 3am which she then takes to the market to sell. She finishes work at 9am. Mrs. P. has used CEPRODEL loans to buy the products she needs to make her dishes at wholesale thereby earning higher profits and improving her standard of living. She started this business in her home with an initial investment of 500 colones that her children gave her.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy firewood, rice, beans, eggs, etc.

loans.name: Nurgul

texts.en:
Nurgul K. is 36, married, and has four children. She was born in a low-income family of farmers.  From her childhood, Nurgul was eager to study and after finishing the 9th grade, she continued her studies in medical college. After graduating, she got a job as a nurse in a local hospital. When Nurgul was 21, she was given in marriage and moved to her husband’s village, where she still lives with the husband’s elderly mother. At present, Nurgul also works as a nurse and is held in high respect by her fellow villagers. 

In rural areas, where the salaries are low and often unstable, it’s very hard to live on low earnings.  That’s why, in order to support her family and find an additional means of substance, Nurgul started her business in cattle breeding using an initial capital of 8,000 KGS. Owing to her persistent and hardworking personality, Nurgul achieved success and today her farm has five milch cows, five sheep, and two horses.  

Nurgul plans to use this loan of 80,000 KGS to add to her cattle. With the revenues from the loan, she plans to give a good education to her children. Also, Nurgul dreams of buying a minivan for her family.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Saom's Group

texts.en:

Mrs. S. Saom is 53 years old. She sells dessert and grilled beef in a local village where she is able to earn a large profit to support her family. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand. So to improve her business, Mrs. S. Saom is applying for a loan to buy more dessert and beef. She is a widow with two children, one of whom is helping her run her business. The other is a security guard.

loans.use: To buy more dessert and beef.

O. se dedica a la venta de granos básicos en el mercado la estación, inicia sus actividades laborales a las 6:00 am y las finaliza a las  4:00 pm, los créditos que le han sido otorgados por  CEPRODEL  ha logrado aumentar su inventario y así ha mejorado su vida familiar realizando mejoras en su vivienda, su núcleo familiar está conformado por 3 hijos y su esposo.

Her nuclear family is composed of her husband and three children.

This has made it possible for her to start up an additional business: underwear sales that has helped her improve her standard of living since she’s a single mother of two daughters.

loans.name: I Made Wirya

texts.en: I Made Wirya is a 53-year-old man living in the town of Melaya - Bali. He is married and has two grown-up children. To make a living, I Made Wirya raises cattle for sale. I Made Wirya has been in this business for over eight years and earns approximately 875,000 Indonesian rupiah (IDR) a month. His favorite part of the job is feeding the cows because it makes him feel at peace. I Made Wirya also owns a chili garden in North Bali. In 2010, I Made Wirya joined MUK to gain access to financial services to help improve his living conditions and enable him to engage in business activities. I Made Wirya is requesting his first loan from MUK. He is requesting a loan of 10,000,000 IDR which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. I Made Wirya plans to use additional revenue to improve and expand his business. About MUK The mission of Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) is to assist small businesses in Bali by providing training, business consultation and loans, thereby helping the owners and their families improve their everyday lives. I Made Wirya 0 (0) merupakan 53 tahun pria. Dia (laki-laki) tinggal di kota Melaya - Bali. Dia (laki-laki) menikah dan memiliki 2 anak usia dewasa. Untuk membiayai hidup, I Made Wirya memiliki & menjalankan usaha. Bisnis beroperasi di sektor pertanian. Tujuan utama bisnis tersebut adalah memelihara ternak. Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari beternak sapi untuk dijual. I Made Wirya sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 8 tahun. Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, I Made Wirya menghasilkan sekitar 875,000 IDR sebulan. Dalam 2010, I Made Wirya bergabung MUK untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis. I Made Wirya telah berhasil melunasi pinjaman sebelumnya dari MUK. Dia (laki-laki) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 10,000,000 IDR. Pinjaman saat ini akan digunakan untuk untuk membeli pakan ternak & pasokan lain. Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 1st pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari MUK. I Made Wirya berencana untuk menggunakan pendapatan tambahan yang dihasilkan dari bisnis untuk meningkatkan/memperluas bisnis peminjam. Tentang MUK: Misi Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) adalah untuk membantu usaha kecil di Bali dengan memberikan perlatihan, konsultasi bisnis, dan pinjaman uang, dengan demikian membantu pemilik usaha dan keluarga mereka memperbaiki hidup sehari-hari. Pesan untuk Peminjam Kiva: Grup ini memakai model pinjaman komunitas/""community lending"" (biasanya dijuluk Bank Desa/""Village Banking"") yang populer di Asia. Di model ini, sejumlah representatif dari grup akan meminjam uang sejumlah lebih besar untuk seluruh grup (kadang-kadang seluruh desa). Representatif ini akan distribusi dan mengendalikan pinjaman, dan mengkoleksi pembayaran untuk peminjam akhir. Ini adalah praktek umum dan efisien di daerah ini, tapi merumitkan cara lapor untuk Kiva. Tidak serupa pinjaman lain, partner Kiva, MUK, akan menjadi kontak utama dengan tim kepemimpinan grup, yang sebaliknya menjadi kontak dengan peminjam akhir. Demikian, jurnal yang ditulis akan merefleksikan hasilnya tim kepemimpinan, bukannya peminjam-peminjam akhir. Untuk belajari lebih banyak tentang Village Banking di Wikipedia, mohon kunjungi website ini: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Village_Banking.

texts.es: Cliente es primer crédito que solicita con nuestra institución para mejora de su vivienda (concluir la construcción de un cuarto), él labora para la universidad Autónoma de Nicaragua (UNAN) León desde hace 6 años  donde se desempeña en cargo de   impresión grafico de libros, recibos folletos etc. Inicia sus labores de 8:00 a 12:00 am y de 1:30 a 6 pm. Su carga familiar es de dos hijos.
texts.en:
This is the first loan he has requested from our institution for home improvements (to complete building a room). He has worked for the Autonomous University of Nicaragua-León Campus for six years. He is in charge of printing books, receipts, brochures, etc. He works from 8am to noon and from 1:30pm to 6pm. He has two children to support.

Enriquieta C. is from Barangay 4, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 45 years old. Enriquieta is married and has 5 school-aged children. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.
