loans.name: Julie Ann

texts.en: Julie Ann S. J., 28 years old, is married to Philip S. J., a driver. The couple is blessed with only one son. These young parents are very industrious and full of dreams. They wish to have a stable business, to build their own house, to send their only child to a better school and to live comfortably and happily. It was 2008 when she joined Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), partner Microfinance Institution of KIVA in the Philippines. She joins ASHI and KIVA because she believes that these institutions can help her achieve her dreams. When she received her loan she used it properly on farming and now she earns a profit. She also maintains very good performance and shows discipline as a member. She is rewarded for her effort. Now, she is applying again for a new loan to use towards their rice field production. This loan will be used to purchase sacks of organic fertilizers, pesticides and to pay for the farm labor. The income from this business will help the couple in their daily needs and in preparation for the future of their children. The couple's plan is to expand their business and to seek an additional income generating project venture in the near future. They are hoping that ASHI and KIVA will always support their plan and their financial needs to be freed from the cycle of poverty.

In 2009, Elsie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Elsie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to to purchase electronic loads to sell. Elsie is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional electronic loads and for working capital. This will be her third loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional electronic loads and for working capital

loans.name: Justine

texts.en: Justine N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Bulenga in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is single and has two children. One of her children is currently in school. Justine has a business running a hotel/restaurant, which she has had for 5 years. To help expand her business, Justine has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase a fridge for drinks for her hotel/restaurant. With the help of this loan from BRAC, Justine hopes to generate greater profits and pay for her child's school fees. In the future, Justine hopes to own a house. Justine is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program which has improved her prospects for the future by teaching her how to maintain her business. Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance. Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans and giving Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: To buy a fridge for drinks

loans.name: Randah

texts.en:
Randah is a 46-year-old married woman living in Tripoli with her husband and four children. Randah sews curtains, bed covers and blankets. She’s a professionA. seamstress, and her customers like the perfection of her work.

Randah is requesting a loan from A. Majmoua in order to buy new textiles that fulfill her customers’ needs. Initially, her problem was that she had only one sewing machine. With her previous loan Randah bought another sewing machine, which made her work more productive and easier. She hopes to continue buying more machines until she can open her own factory.

loans.use: To buy new textiles

loans.name: Vichet

texts.en:
Mr. Vichet N., is 31 years old and his wife, Mrs. Phary Phat (pictured), is 28 years old. They live in a village along National Road Number Two approximately 13 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 2009 and have two sons. One of them attends school and another one is still too young for school. His wife stays at home and takes care of their sons.

Vichet is an ice deliveryman. He buys ice and then delivers it to customers who have businesses that require ice, such as people who sell cold drinks or noodles. Vichet lends coolers to his new customers to keep the ice cold. He needs to buy more coolers for his customers, but he does not have money.  Therefore, he is applying for his first loan of $700 in order to make the purchases.  

Vichet is not in the photo. Instead, his wife was available for the photo.

loans.use: To use for his ice delivery business

loans.name: Sambo

texts.en:
Mrs. Sambo M. (pictured), 32, and her husband, Mr. Ratha Phann, 42, were married in 1996 and have three daughters. All of them are in school. The family lives in a small village about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Sambo has been selling fish and vegetables for 14 years. Her husband has full-time employment. The couple is in the process of building their new house to stay in, but they lack some money to finish it. 

Hence, Sambo is asking for her first loan of $1,100 to finish her house and build a fence around it.

loans.use: To finish her house and build a fence around it

Musa is a fisherman. His wife sells the fish that her husband caught. Because he does not have enough fishing materials to work with, he decided to ask for a loan of $800 to purchase fishing nets for his business. 

Musa was not available for the photo. His wife is pictured instead.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets for his fishing business

The main source of income for the business comes from selling sweets and confectioneries such as gulaman (jellied) candies in the local community. Narcisa has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities. Narcisa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Narcisa is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the third loan taken out by Narcisa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. loans.name: Sreyroth

texts.en:
Miss Sreyroth C. (shown in the photo) is 33 and single. She lives with her parents, brother and sisters on an island on the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Sreyroth has been a weaver for a year. She sells her finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh market. Sreyroth has two looms to use and she wants to buy one more loom and additional weaving materials for her business so she is asking for a loan of 1,100 USD to make the purchases.

loans.use: To buy a loom and  weaving materials

loans.name: Yat

texts.en:
Mrs Yat P. (shown in the photo with her loom) and her husband, Mr Chanthorn But, were married in 1987 and have two daughters. Both of their daughters are married. One of their daughters lives outside the family home. Her daughter and her son-in-law are silk weavers. The family lives on an Island on Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs Yat P. has been a silk weaver since 1980. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village who takes it to sell in Phnom Penh. She is requesting a loan of $100 to purchase silk material to continue her weaving.

loans.use: To buy silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en: Sophia B. is an individual client from Kampala. Her dream is to build and expand her business selling second hand clothes. She has been operating for the last three years in the old taxi park and in Kalerwe-Kampala. Sophia is a single mother of two school-going children. Her plan is to buy more clothes to resell once she receives this loan. She credits her cousin with helping her get off her feet in this business. Prior to beginning this business, she was selling mostly gomesi, which is a garment particularly in high favor with old women in the rural areas for traditional functions. Her small business, notwithstanding its many challenges, generates close to 150,000 UGX a week. She attributes this to hard work, good customer care and a sense of friendliness. She says this loan will come in handy in helping her expand her business. In her estimation, she will be able to buy more clothes and establish a vantage place for her growing business, which means more profits.

loans.use: To purchase more bales of second hand clothes to sell

Esterlita has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Esterlita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes A., age 51, and her husband, Remy, have six children.  Three of their children are working, one is in college, one is in high school, and one is in elementary school.  Lourdes works hard to cover the family's daily expenses and to pay for the children's education.  

Lourdes has applied for a loan of PHP 10,000 to help her purchase additional seeds and fertilizer for her farm.  Crop failures and pests can make her farming an unpredictable business and the loan should help her ensure than she can continue to generate income.  

Lourdes has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) through several loan cycles and has consistently attended weekly fellowship meetings.*  She hopes that her children will successfully complete their education and that over time her farming business will expand.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Him

texts.en:

Him has been a silk weaver since she was 16 yeas old. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village who will take them to sell in Phnom Penh. She is requesting her first loan of $250 to purchase silk materials for her weaving.

loans.use: To buy silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Narantuya

texts.en:

She began to trade various kind of food products in 2000 and now she has a stable business operation. She is a very diligent and hard-working person who supports her entire family through her food-trading business. She purchases food products at wholesale prices and sells them at retail prices in her local town.  

Narantuya is requesting a 3,900,000 MNT loan for working capital in order to expand her business and improve her food selection.

loans.name: Ganhuyag

texts.en: Ganhuyag S. is 48 years old and lives in the Huvsgul province in western Mongolia. He lives with his wife and two children in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His daughter is currently attending a university in Mongolia's capital city, Ulaanbaatar, and his son helps his father with the family business. Ganhuyag's wife is employed at a local school as a teacher. Ganhuyag runs a wooden products manufacturing business in his town. He makes a variety of wooden products such as furniture. He started his business in 2001 and has had moderate success. He must design, produce and paint all of his products by hand because he can't afford the necessary tools and equipment. He has found it difficult to save his business earnings and has put all his money into paying his daughter's tuition fees. He says, "My son will soon be married, so I must support him so that he can live separately from his mother and I." Ganhuyag is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to buy more wood and tools to increase his working capital.

loans.use: To buy more wood and tools

loans.name: Praise Development Group-Mukono

texts.en: L. Jude has been selling belts for the last 4 years to help him financially support himself, his wife and child. He belongs to the Praise development group in Mukono.  Jude started off as an employee in a retail shop before he nursed the idea of starting this business. He says hard work and determination have been his trump cards in an increasingly competitive belt selling hawker retail business.  In a month, he makes profits that add up to 120,000 shillings. With this loan, Jude is high on optimism that he will be able to purchase more belts that he will resell and henceforth accrue more profits.

loans.use: The purchase of more belts for resell

loans.name: Mrs Un Long Hong Village Bank Group

texts.en: Pou Roung village in Takeo province has 19 people who are seeking a village bank loan. Mrs U. L. H., who was born in 1959, is the village bank president selected by the other members. They will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes. Mrs U. L. H. owns a general store in a local village where she sells groceries to earn a large profit to support her family. Her husband, Mr MoeU. Khiev, is a farmer and policeman who owns a small piece of land used to cultivate rice to sell to support his family. Since Mrs U. L. H.'s business is going well, she wants to expand, so she is applying for a loan to buy more groceries to sell to improve her business. She is a mother of three children: one of whom is helping her to sell groceries, one is a driver, and the other is studying in school.

loans.name: Bumu Development Group

texts.en:
A. Rose is a 42-year-old, good natured, suave, and happily-married mother to four high-spirited kids. She belongs to Bumu Development Group in Mukono.

Rose’s track record in the groundnut (peanut) sales business that she oversees, spans a period of over four years. With persistence and hard work, her business has seen the light of day up to now, notwithstanding the financial adversity that has plagued it. With this loan, she is hoping to improve on her only dependable source of livelihood.

Rose says she is going to buy more containers for her groundnut paste, processors, and more groundnut paste. This she says will be some kind of rebranding and reinvention for her business. She is hoping this will translate into more sales for her product.

Rose traces the advent of her business journey back to a pig husbandry enterprise that she still runs, though it now plays second fiddle to the aforementioned. In a week, her profits total up to 40,000 shillings.

loans.use: To purchase more containers, processors and groundnut paste

Teresita plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is 43 years old and a single mother of one. She has raised her child using the income from her salon.

Lucy’s business is located in a very busy environment and most of her customers are middle and low income earners. She hopes to stabilize the business, which she has been running for twelve years. She believes that, with a stable business, she will be able to employ more people.

Lucy has requested a loan of 70,000 Kes to buy plastic chairs, a hairdrier and mirrors. She wants her salon to look classic so as to attract more customers in the future. She describes herself as a hardworking lady.

loans.use: To buy plastic chairs, a hairdrier and mirrors

She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP whenever she sells a raised animal. This loan will be her 4th from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Rosenie owns and operates a business providing transportation services to local community members with her husband as the driver of the motorcycle. Rosenie is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. loans.name: Jonathan

texts.en:
Jonathan runs a cyber café to earn a living. He has been running the business for six years and has two employees. He also sells cereals to supplement his family’s income.

Jonathan is a member of Ushindi Kala group in Faulu Kenya which has guaranteed his loan of 40,000 KES. He will use the loan to buy more chairs, tables and printer paper.

Jonathan hopes to expand the business and be in a position to educate his four children. In ten years, he wants to have more business outlets in Nairobi.

loans.use: To buy more chairs, tables and printer paper

Jeanciana owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Jeanciana is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 4th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. loans.name: Stalamarice

texts.en:
Stalamarice is a single mother of two. She has engaged in a tailoring business for fifteen years and also farms for extra income.

Stalamarice is a member of Maarifa group in Faulu Kenya. She has requested a loan of 30,000 KES through the group to buy fabric. She hopes to build a homestead for herself in the future.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is married and has two children aged 10 and 6. For a living, she sells children’s wear and has been in this business for ten years. She also does outside catering to earn more income.

Since she joined Faulu Kenya, Esther has learnt new ways of doing business. She has requested a loan of 30,000 Kes which she will use to buy T-shirts and tops and to meet transportation expenses.

Esther hopes to buy a plot of land in the future. She describes herself as a hardworking and determined lady.

loans.use: To buy T-shirts and tops and to meet transportation expenses

loans.name: Joilyn

texts.en:
Joilyn A. is from the village of Manila Group, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 32 years old and is married with 3 school-aged children.

Joilyn owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling shellfish in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Joilyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell.

Joilyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 4th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 


About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

location.town: Manila Group, Wao, Lanao del Sur

loans.name: Rosejean

texts.en:
This is Rosejean B., 33, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Zacarias B., a driver, and is the mother of a youngster of high school age. By the grace of God, Rosejean has managed to support her child’s schooling and is working hard to be able to send her child all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Rosejean; she, herself, has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

With her husband, Rosejean operates a fleet of jeepneys (small buses) and tricycles. Together, they manage finances, find drivers for the jeepneys and tricycle, collect money and basically heed every concern of their drivers about the vehicles. Zacarias also drives one of the jeepneys.

To help her continue operations of her business, Rosejean is requesting a Php 16,000 loan. She will use the loan to manage repair needs of the vehicles and legal follow-ups like licenses and registrations. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Rosejean dreams of being able to give her child a good and high-quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets every week with her co-fellowship members* to share stories of her work.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To manage the repair needs of her vehicles and pay licenses and registrations

texts.en: Denis G. is from the village of Parog Parog, Solana, Cagayan. She is 28 years old and is married with one infant child. Denis owns and operates a business planting and selling different vegetables in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. Denis joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. Denis is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This loan will be her 4th from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Akarusho Group

texts.fr:
Esperance N. est une commerçante âgée de 30 ans qui habite la Commune urbaine de Nyakabiga en Mairie de Bujumbura. Elle fait le commerce de produits de boutique  au quartier Nyakabiga il ya de cela 10 ans. Elle a fait ses études primaires jusqu’en 6e année. Son époux, Henri Bigirimana, est employé chez Air Burundi. Elle  participe dans le crédit solidaire avec Turame. 

Elle a 4 enfants âgés successivement de 13ans, 10ans, 7ans et 5ans qui étudient.
  
Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour  augmenter la quantité des produits de boutique en vue  de réaliser un grand bénéfice. Elle espère avoir une parcelle pour construire sa propre maison mais souhaite aussi que ses enfants finissent leurs études avec succès afin de mener une vie meilleure. Son business a commencé avec un petit capital mais se développe petit à petit avec le temps. 
 Elle est une des membres du groupe  solidaire « AKARUSHO ».
texts.en:
Esperance N. is a 30-year old entrepreneur who lives in the urban commune of Nyakabiga, of Bujumbura Mairie. She sells various dry goods in the district of Nyakabiga. She has finished primary studies until the 6th school year. Her husband, Henri Bigiramana, works for Air Burundi. She participates in the solidarity loan program of Turame Community Credit. She has four children, aged 13, 10, 7, and 5 years respectively; all go to school. She is seeking a loan from Kiva in order to increase the stock of various articles in her store and to increase her revenues. She is hoping to be able to purchase a land plot to have her own house built; also, she would like her children to complete their studies successfully and lead a better life. Her business was launched with a small starting capital but has grown gradually over time. She is a member of the Akarusho solidarity group.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: augmenter la quantité des produits de boutique en vue  de réaliser un grand bénéfice

Adalhia owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste and herbal products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Adalhia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Adalhia is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 5th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
This is Rebecca B., 53, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Carlos B., a driver, and is the mother of two children.

Rebecca operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 pesos-worth of cooking oil, or an egg.

Rebecca earns her income by buying supplies at the wholesale price and selling retail in single quantities. Her store is located adjacent to her house and her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 200 in sales every day.

To help her continue the operation of her business, Rebecca is requesting a Php 16,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
 
Rebecca dreams of being able to give both of her children a good and high-quality education through all her hard work in her business. She also hopes to soon have a new business, preferable her own jeepney which her husband can drive. She faithfully meets every week with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Twekembe Kikooza Group – Mukono

texts.en: N. Joyce, 46 years old, belongs to Twekembe Kikooza group in Mukono. She is a courteous, good-natured, approachable married woman with six kids. To make ends meet, she has been selling charcoal for the last six years in Kikooza-Mukono. She makes profits that add up to 50,000 shillings in a week. She has had to deal with a number of setbacks including the lack of finances to buy more bags of charcoal. She is hoping that with this loan she will have a favorable turn in her financial circumstances and will have money to buy bags of charcoal more often. She says her business will bask in the glow of more success if she buys more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en: Teresita V. is from the village of Parog Parog, Solana, Cagayan. She is 51 years old and is married with four adult children. Teresita owns and operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP whenever she sells a raised animal. Teresita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to expand the shelter for her pigs. This loan will be her 2nd from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Mrs. Sar Mom Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twenty-two people make up a village bank located in Pou Roung village in Takeo province. All the members have selected Mrs. Sar M., born in 1971, to be the village bank president. Each member will use their portion of the loan in various ways to support their businesses in this current year. 

Mrs. Sar M. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Kha Chiv, is a recyclable goods seller and he is also a construction worker. Since her husband’s business is going well, she wants to expand it. To improve his business, Mrs. Sar M. is requesting a loan to buy more recyclable goods to sell. She is a mother of three children who are all studying in school, and they are also helping their parents’ businesses.

loans.use: To buy more recyclable goods to sell

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima is a 55-year-old married woman from Tyre, Lebanon, who is the mother of a single child.

Since 1999, Fatima has worked in the distillation of herbs. Other than her husband’s work, it’s her main source of income and she helps him in supporting the family.

This is Fatima’s fourth loan. She’s requesting the loan in order to buy special herbs and flowers and bottles necessary to save the distilled herbs. Her clients are her neighbors, relatives, friends and friends of friends, or anyone interested in such industry.

Fatima is an expert in her work, and that’s what’s keeping her strong in the market. She hopes to open her own factory to produce her products under a registered trademark.

loans.use: To buy special herbs, flowers and bottles

loans.name: Emma

texts.en: Emma P. is from the village of Baylao, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 46 years old and is married with two school-aged children. Emma owns and operates a business making and selling food, primarily selling snacks and other delicacies like banana cakes and banana cues (deep-fried banana covered with caramelized brown sugar) in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Emma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding her business. Emma is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Hem

texts.en:
Hem V. has been spending most of her life cultivating crops. This is a skill she learned from her grandparent when she was young. She is now married and has five children, three of whom are employed at different jobs. Her husband works in the farm fields, frequently alongside her.

Growing crops is an annual operation with which Hem V. has had great success. She is able to plant the crops at least twice a year by following both rainy and dry seasons.

The farmland that Hem V. owns is located far from the water and the irrigation of her crops has been affected. To help solve this problem, she is looking for a loan to buy a water pump to deliver the water to her crops.

loans.use: To buy a water pump to irrigate her crops

loans.name: Ricarda

texts.en: Ricarda C. is from the village of Yumbing, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 54 years old and is married with eight adult children. Ricarda owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling bananas and charcoal in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over thirty years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Ricarda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Ricarda is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Urukan's Group

texts.en:
Urukan A., 47 and married, is the leader of this group. She has two children, an 8-year-old daughter and a 17-year-old son, both attending school. Four years ago, Urukan started cattle breeding with an initial investment of 30000 soms, and now earns 15000 each month. Also, with the help of profits from cattle breeding, she has been able to build a house and buy more cattle. She is requesting a loan in order to buy fertilizers, and in the future plans to open a confectionery.

Group members: Patihan S., a 49-year-old widow, is treasurer of the group. She has four children: her sons are 27 and 19, and her daughters are 21 and 17 years old. Patihan started farming 14 years ago with an initial investment of 300 soms, and now earns 5000 soms each month. She is applying for a loan in order to buy fertilizers.

Irishan H., 50 years old and married, has four children: her sons are 19 and 9 years old and her daughters are 16 and 12 years old. Her eldest son works in Russia, while her eldest daughter is a student at an institution of higher education and her youngest children go to school. Assisted by her husband, Irishan is a farmer who also breeds cattle. She started farming and cattle breeding 14 years ago with an initial investment of 500 soms, and now earns 3000 soms each month. She is applying for a loan in order to buy fertilizers. In the future, she is planning to build a house with the help of her profits from farming and cattle breeding.

Sultanbai S., 42 and married, has two children, a six-month-old daughter and a seven-year-old who goes to school. His wife takes care of the home. Sultanbai started farming 20 years ago with an initial investment of 700 soms, and he currently earns 5000 soms per month from cattle breeding. He is applying for a loan in order to buy fertilizers, and in the future plans to reinvest all of his profits in order to increase his future profits.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
This is Leonora C., 55, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Nelson C., a driver, and mother of six children.

Leonora operates a rug-making business. She mainly offers rugs ranging from round palm-sized ones to the much larger doormats, braided quilts and bed sheets, and other crafts that most rug-makers make everyday. Since they are a major part of Filipino housekeeping and cleaning, rugs are among the most common products that can be bought, sometimes even from a peddler while one is riding in a speeding jeepney down the highway. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php200 in sales each day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php33,000 loan to buy more quantities of raw materials including fabrics, thread and newspapers for patterns. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Leonora dreams of being able to meet all the needs of her family, and faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. Each fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of raw materials such as fabrics, thread and newspapers for patterns

loans.name: Heng

texts.en: Mrs. Heng S. is a 30-year-old married woman living in a medium-sized home with family members in Phnom Penh City.  Heng uses a piece of farmland she inherited many years ago from her grandparents to grow a variety of crops, receiving help in the planting from her husband.  She will use half of the loan she is requesting to grow crops, and the rest will be put towards buying a used pumping machine for her field.

loans.use: To grow crops.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter is 26 years old and has a two-year-old child.  He is a member of Kamahindu Victory Group with Faulu Kenya, where he saves his money.  He does dairy farming to earn a living.  He has been in the business for five years.  He also does crop farming.  He has requested a loan of 30,000 Kenyan shillings to buy manure, farm inputs and fertilizer.  He hopes to improve his farming in the future.  He sees himself becoming a large-scale farmer in five years.

loans.use: To buy manure, farm inputs and fertilizers

loans.name: Ceremie

texts.en:
Ceremie B. is from the village of Tagdo, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 21 years old. Ceremie is married and has 2 infant children. To make a living, Ceremie owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Ceremie has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Ceremie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ceremie is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Ceremie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Antony

texts.en:
Antony is a 31-year-old father of two, aged four and one. He says that he is committed to his work which is selling charcoal.  From this business, he earns a living.  He has been running the business for three years with two employees. 

 Antony became a member of Faulu Kenya through Funga Leso group. Since he became part of Faulu Kenya, he has become dilligent in his work.  He hopes to expand his business and become independent in five years.  He is requesting a loan of 20,000 Kes to buy bags of charcoal.

loans.use: To buy bags of charcoal for sale

loans.name: Meilikan's Group

texts.en:
Meilikan K. is the leader of this group. She is forty-nine and married. She has two children: her son is twelve and her daughter is nine. Both of them go to school. Her husband is a taxi driver.

Meilikan farms and sells barley. She started farming barley two years ago in accordance with a decision taken by Meilikan and her husband. She started with an initial investment of 1,500 soms and she makes 3,000 soms monthly. With the profits from farming, she was able to buy cattle. So, now she also breeds cattle. She is applying for a loan in order to buy more cattle and one ton of cement to build the foundation for her house. In the future, she is planning to continue construction of her house. 

Group members:

Suiumkan D. is treasurer of the group. She is twenty-three and divorced. She also breeds cattle. Three years ago, she bought a calf for 12,000 soms and started breeding cattle. She plans to increase her turnover so she is applying for a loan. With the help of the loan she will buy cattle and continue cattle breeding. With the profits from cattle breeding, she plans to build a house. She is pregnant.

Asanbai D. is sixty-two and married. He has seven children: his sons are twenty-six, twenty-three, twenty-two and his daughters are twenty, twelve and eleven years old. His elder children are sellers and his youngest two daughters go to school. Asanbai is a farmer and breeds cattle. Eighteen years ago, he decided to start cattle breeding and farming with an initial investment of 1,500 soms. His current monthly income from cattle breeding and farming is 3,000 soms. With the profits from cattle breeding, he was able to make capital repairs at his house and buy a car. He is applying for a loan in order to have sufficient funds to finance cultivating crops. With the profits from farming and cattle breeding, he is planning to marry off his sons and build a house. 

Akdana A. is twenty-seven and married. She has six children: her sons are eight and seven years old and 4 months; her daughters are five and four years old. Her two elder sons go to school, while the others are still at home. Her husband is a mullah. Akdana breeds cattle. Four years ago, after she married, she started cattle breeding with an initial investment of 2,000 soms. Now, cattle breeding brings her 1,500 som monthly. She is applying for a loan to buy cattle to increase her turnover and her profits. With the profits from cattle breeding, she has already bought a house and furniture. In the future, she is planning to spend the profits from cattle breeding on providing higher education to her children and improving the family's living conditions.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Lucky Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Lucky Group” from Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are petty businesswomen who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, in order to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 for each in the group. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and profit, and consequently improve their living conditions. 

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Isata B.. Isata was born in Kenema, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. The thirty-seven-year-old is married and has three children. Her husband is a motor-bike driver and her children are attending primary school. Isata sells bread and flour. She will use her share of this loan to buy flour wholesale.

loans.use: Buy flour wholesale

loans.name: Hilario

texts.en:
Hilario P. is from the village of Kiburiao, Quezon, Bukidnon. He is 44 years old. Hilario is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Hilario owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Hilario has been engaged in his business for over 11 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 1997, Hilario joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Hilario has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Hilario is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 23rd loan taken out by Hilario from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital

loans.name: Turduhan's Group

texts.en:
Turduhan D. is the leader of this group. She is sixty and married. She has seven children: her sons are forty-one, thirty-nine, thirty-seven, thirty-two, twenty-eight, twenty-two and her daughter is thirty-three. All her children work as sellers at “Dordoi” market in Bishkek (the capital of Kyrgyzstan) and each of them sends their mother 6,000 soms monthly. Her husband is farmer, and she breeds cattle. Twenty years ago, she started to breed livestock with initial investment of 1000 soms. Now, reselling some livestock after fattening and at a higher price, she makes 3,000 soms per month. She is applying for a loan in order to buy four sheep and increase her turnover and as a result her profits. In the future, she is planning to celebrate the marriage of one of her sons. 

Group members:

Zymyrat K. is treasurer of the group. She is forty-six and married. She has four children: her sons are twenty-three and twenty-one, and her daughters are twenty-three and twenty-one. Her sons works as builders in Russia and their monthly income is 25,000 soms. Her husband is a taxi driver. Zymyrat breeds cattle and sews traditional clothing. She started twenty-four years ago with an initial investment of 1,000 soms. Now, cattle breeding and sewing traditional clothing brings her 1,500 soms monthly. She is applying for a loan to buy more cattle and increase her turnover. With the profits from cattle breeding, she is planning to help her sons enter institutions of higher education.
 
Nurzhamal T. is forty-eight and married. She has five children: her sons are eighteen, thirteen, and nineteen, and her daughters are twenty-four and twenty-two years old. Her daughters work in a sewing workshop, while Nurzhamal breeds cattle. She started cattle breeding twenty-eight years ago with initial investment of 1,000 soms. With the help of cattle breeding, she earns 1,500 soms monthly. She is applying for a loan to buy more cattle. In the future, she is planning to help her sons establish themselves in life.

Narynbek I. is twenty-two and single. He lives with his mother who is a farmer. He breeds cattle. Two years ago, he started with a purchase of cattle for 1,000 soms. Monthly, he now earns 1,500 soms from cattle breeding. He is applying for a loan in order to purchase additional cattle to raise. In the future, with the help of profits from cattle breeding, he plans to marry. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep

loans.name: Sabenti Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Sabenti” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Makama, on the outskirts of Makeni, in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 500,000 for each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Gbassay B.. Gbassay is age thirty-five and was born in Makama village. She is married with three children. Her husband is a teacher. Two of her children are attending primary school and one is in secondary school.  For many years now, Gbassay has been selling caustic soda, costume jewelry and cloth. She will use her share of the loan to buy the above-mentioned goods in large quantity to add to her business.

loans.use: Buy caustic soda, costume jewelry, and cloth

loans.name: Scola

texts.en: Scola is a married lady who is blessed with a two-year-old child.  She operates "Scola Beauty Place".  She has been running the business for three years and has two employees.  She joined Faulu Kenya in a group called Funga Leso.  Since she joined the group, she has learnt how to keep track of her business progress.  She is requesting a loan of 15,000 Kes to purchase hair chemicals, weaves, braids, cosmetics and a blow-dryer.  Scola is very ambitious and she sees herself running a big beauty parlour in the future.

loans.use: To purchase hair chemicals, weaves, braids, cosmetics and a blow-dryer

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Eunice is a mother of three children who go to school.  She is a 32-year-old member of Blessed Kawaida group, registered under Faulu Kenya where she saves her money.  Since 2007, she has been selling charcoal together with her husband.  Besides, she runs a grocery store.  She has requested a loan of 50,000 KES which she will use to add to her stock of charcoal.  She sees herself owning real estate in the future.

loans.use: To add to her stock of charcoal

loans.name: Muong

texts.en:
Mr. Muong M. is an older man whose wife appears in the photograph above. To earn a living, Muong M. uses his own motorcycle to provide taxi service. He travels around the local market where he always picks passengers up. His wife, Sarim, age 44, is a requirement laborer. The couple has two single children, while their other three children are already married and live independently. 

Muong M. has bought a neighbor’s land in a good location for farming, on which he hopes to raise crops to earn additional income. However, Muong M. doesn’t have farm supplies to use on his field, and this is why Muong M. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer, a pump, and seed to plant.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, a pump, and seed for planting

loans.name: Alissone

texts.pt:
Alissone M. nasceu no Distrito de Boane, Província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique, pai de 5 filhos de idades entre 9 a 19 anos de idade, todos vão a Escola. Fez somente 6ª classe não continuou devido a guerra de desestabilização. Vive na casa própria e não sustenta mais ninguém para além dos filhos.

Nunca saiu da sua terra natal, trabalha numa instituição que também funciona como orfanato é tratorista ha mais de 20 anos na empresa e tem um salario de 4.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda consegue poupar algum em sua casa.

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de colegas que também são clientes da instituição. Este é o seu primeiro empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (carne, cerveja, refrescos, vinho, água e outros) para iniciar um actividade comercial para a sua esposa.
 
No futuro gostaria de pedir um novo empréstimo para aumentar e diversificar ainda mais a minha mercadoria para satisfazer a demanda da clientela.
texts.en:
Alissone M. was born in the Boane district, in the Maputo province, which is in the south of Mozambique. He is the father of 5 children, who are between 9 and 19 years old, all of whom attend school. He attended through 6th grade himself but did not continue his studies because of a destabilizing war. He lives in his own home and doesn't support anyone else beside his children.

He has never left his native land. He works for an orphanage where he drives a tractor, which he has done for more than 20 years. He has a monthly salary of 4,000MT, which he uses to pay for his household expenses and he saves some as well.

He has never taken loans from other banks. He came to know Hluvuku through some colleagues who are also clients of the institution. This is his first loan, for the amount of 15,000MT, which he will use to purchase products like meat, beer, snacks, wine, water, etc. to launch a business with his wife.

In the future, he would like to seek a new loan to increase and diversify his merchandise even more to satisfy the demand of his clients.

Translated from Portuguese by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of products (meat, beer, snacks, wine, water, etc.)

loans.name: Sam-Try Group

texts.en:
These are members of the Sam-Try Group. They run small-scale businesses based in Makama, on the outskirts of Makeni, in Northern Sierra Leone. This will be their first loan from SMT/Kiva. With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and better profit. Consequently, their living conditions will improve:  they will at least be able to provide three meals a day for their children, pay their school fees, buy them clothes to wear, and pay their medical bills in case any of them falls sick. 

Aminata K. is the leader of this group. Aminata was born in Makama village. She is 42 years of age, married to a lorry driver and they have one child who is attending secondary school. Aminata sells rice, cooking oil, pepper, etc. She has been running this business for seven years now. With the help of this loan, Aminata will buy more stock to add to her business.

loans.use: To buy rice, cooking oil, pepper, etc.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes has been a dairy farmer for four years.  She is 26 years old and has two children.  She hopes to improve her farming in the future.  Now, she is requesting a loan of 35,000 Kenyan shillings from Faulu Kenya.  With the loan, she will buy a cow.  She sees herself buying a plot of land and building rental houses in the future.  She describes herself as a hardworking and focused lady.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Julieta David

texts.pt:
Julieta David C. nasceu no Distrito de Boane, Província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique, mãe de 6 filhos, destes 4 vão a Escola. Não freqüentou a escola os pais na altura priorizavam a machamba e pastagens de gado. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e tem ajudado seus irmãos em algumas despesas alimentares.

Nunca saiu da sua terra natal, trabalha na machamba como agricultor com o seu marido como base de sustentabilidade da família. O marido recebe uma pensão de desmobilizado no valor de 5.159.00mt que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum de vez enquanto na sua casa.
 
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de vizinhos que também são clientes da instituição. Este é o seu primeiro empréstimo no valor de 10.300.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (ferro, cimento, arame, chapas de zinco e outros) para iniciar a sua obra de construção da sua residência.
 
No futuro gostaria de pedir um novo empréstimo para dar continuidade com a construção da sua casa para sair das condições em que vive atualmente.
texts.en:
Julieta David C. was born in the Boane district, in the Maputo province, which is in the south of Mozambique. She is the mother of 6 children, of whom 4 attend school. She did not attend school, as at that point her parents prioritized their machamba (small agricultural field) and cattle pasture. She lives in her own home with her family and they are helping her siblings with a few expenses.

She has never left her native land. She has worked in her machamba as a farmer with her husband to support their family. Her husband receives a military pension in the amount of 5,159MT, which they use to pay for household expenses and to save from time to time.

She has never taken a loan from another bank. She learned of Hluvuku through some neighbors who are also clients of the institution. This is her first loan, for the amount of 10,300MT, which she will use to buy construction materials (iron, cement, wire, zinc plates, etc.) to begin construction on her home.

In the future, she would like to seek additional loans to continue construction on her home to improve the living conditions for her family.

Translated from Portuguese by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials (iron, cement, wire, zinc plates, etc.)

loans.name: Jilina Antonio

texts.pt:
Jilina Antônio S. nasceu na cidade de Maputo, Província do mesmo nome, sul de Moçambique, mãe de 2 filhos, o mais velho vai a Escola. Fez somente 7ª classe, não continuou devido a gravidez precoce. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e não sustenta ninguém.

Nunca saiu de Maputo, faz a criação de frangos para abate ha mais de 5 anos. Não possui nenhum empregado e consegue um rendimento de cerca de 3.500.00mt a 4.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancaria.
 
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de amigas que também são clientes da instituição. Este é o seu primeiro empréstimo no valor de 9.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar pintos, ração e vitaminas para reforçar o seu stock.

No futuro pretende solicitar um novo empréstimo para reforçar ainda mais o seu negócio de forma a responder a demanda da sua clientela.
texts.en:
Jilina Antônio S. was born in the city of Maputo, in the province of the same name, in the south of Mozambique. She is the mother of two children, the eldest of which attends school. She attended through 7th grade but did not continue because of her pregnancy. She lives in her own home with her family and doesn't support anyone else.

She has never left Maputo, and has been raising chickens for more than 5 years. She doesn't have any employees and she has a monthly income of about 3,500MT to 4,000MT, which she applies to her household expenses and saves the rest to her bank account.

She has never taken out a loan from another bank. She got to know Hluvuku through her friends who are also clients of the institution. This is her first loan for the amount of 9,000MT with which she plans to purchase more chicks, feed, and vitamins to reinforce her stock.

In the future, she hopes to seek a new loan to further reinforce her business and respond to the demand of her clients.

Translated from Portuguese by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of chicks, feed, and vitamins

loans.name: Khel

texts.en:
Mr. Khel A. has been working at cultivating crops since before he married. He is now married and has seven children. Two of them are no longer in school and work as farmers. Khel A. has a partner in his wife who works in the farm fields frequently alongside him. 

Growing crops is an annual job with which he has had great success. He is able to plant the crops at least twice a year by taking advantage of both rainy and dry seasons. Mr. Khel A. is taking out his loan to purchase a pump to irrigate his crops. He intends to use any remaining cash from the loan to buy more farm supplies for his field.

loans.use: To purchase a pump to irrigate his crops

loans.name: Dinis Samuel

texts.pt:
Dinis Samuel T. nasceu no Distrito de Boane, Província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique, pai de 2 filhos de 1 e 5 anos de idade, ainda não vão a Escola. Fez somente 7ª classe, não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras por parte dos progenitores. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e não sustenta ninguém para além da sua família.

Nunca saiu de Boane, é pedreiro de profissão mas faz negocio de venda de produtos de primeira necessidade com a sua esposa ha mais de 1 ano. Não possui nenhum empregado e consegue um rendimento de cerca de 10.000.00mt a 12.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancaria.
 
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de amigos que também são clientes da instituição. Este é o seu primeiro empréstimo no valor de 10.300.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (arroz, feijão, amendoim, massas e outros) para aumentar quantidade da sua mercadoria.

No futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para desenvolver ainda mais o seu negocio e transformar se em um grande empreendedor.
texts.en:
Dinis Samuel was born in the Boane District, in the Maputo Province, South of Mozambique. He is the father of two children who are one and five years old and not yet in school. He only went to school until 7th grade and didn't finish due to his parents lack of financial conditions. He lives in his own home with his family and doesn't support anyone other than them. He has never left Boane. He is a bricklayer by trade but has had a business selling groceries with his wife for more than a year. He doesn't have any employees and has an income of around 10,000 to 12,000 meticais per month, which is spent in household expenses. He also manages to save some in his bank account. He has never had loans from other banks. He became familiar with Hluvuku through friends who are also partners of this institution. This is his first loan, in the amount of 10,300 meticais. He intends to buy products (rice, beans, peanuts, pasta and others) to increase his inventory. He intend to request more loans in the future to further develop his business and to become a great entrepreneur.

Translated from Portuguese by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of inventory (rice, beans, peanuts, pasta and others)

loans.name: Evans

texts.en: Evans is 29 years old and married with two children.  He does photography together with his wife and has one employee.  He has been running Evan’s Photo Shop for seven years.  He hopes that one day he will expand his business and employ more people.  He has requested a loan of 20,000 KES to buy another camera.  For this loan, he has been guaranteed by Shirley’s Group in Faulu Kenya where he is a member.  He hopes to manage his own company in ten years.  He describes himself as hardworking, focused, and ambitious.

loans.use: To buy a camera

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 30 years old and married.  He is a hardworking man who owns and runs a retail shop.  He hopes to expand the business in the future.  He is a member of Destiny Group under Faulu Kenya.  In the group, the members save money, guarantee each other loans, and share business ideas.

Daniel has requested a loan of 20,000 KES through the group.  With the loan, he will buy wheat flour.  He sees himself expanding his business into a big wholesale business.

loans.use: To buy wheat flour

loans.name: Minerva

texts.en:
This is Minerva F., 41, resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. Already widowed at such a young age; she manages to be mother and father to four children, one of whom is already in high school, while the younger children are enrolled in elementary school. By the grace of God, Minerva has managed to support her older child's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send all of them all the way through college--a dream for most Filipino parents like Minerva as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Minerva operates a food stall where her main products are mostly breakfast fare. In the Philippines, the whole working community and most of the families only eat home-cooked meals in the evenings when all of the family members are at home to take part in the meal. This is not only a usual family tradition but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to spend cooking gas and food for one or two people when buying cooked rice and viands costs less than raw food. Minerva's regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 15,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more products such as meat, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Minerva dreams of being able to give all her children a good, high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also hopes to have her own stall someday, so that she can save her rent money and use it for her children. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy more products such as meat, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en:
This is Geraldine L., 34, resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Samuel L., a car air conditioner technician, and mother of three children, all of whom are already in high school. By the grace of God, Geraldine has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send all of them all the way through college--a dream for most Filipino parents like Geraldine as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Geraldine maintains a direct sales business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct sales brands. A customers order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalogue, and these are the profits that dealers are investing on as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 2000 in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php14,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Geraldine dreams to be able to give all her children a good, high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy orders for her customers

loans.name: Sorbeh - Ii Group

texts.en:
These women run small-scale businesses in Makama, on the outskirts of Makeni city, in Northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, seeking a loan of 500,000 leones each to enable them to expand their businesses. With the loan, they will be able to add more stock to their businesses and make more sales and profit. Consequently, they will be able to improve their standard of living and send their children to school and feed and clothe them. 

Adamsay G. is the leader of this group. She was born in Makama village 35 years ago. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a teacher and her children are attending primary school. Adamsay sells sugar, cooking oil, rice, etc. She has been running this business for two years now. With her share of the loan, she will expand her business by buying more stock wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.use: To buy sugar, cooking oil, rice, etc.

loans.name: Learn To Pay Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Learn to Pay” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Kadiatu K.. For ten years now, she has been selling dishes and clothes. With this loan,  Kadiatu will buy dishes and clothes wholesale to add to her business inventory. Kadiatu is aged twenty-seven; she was born in Makeni, where she is currently residing together with her husband and three children. Her husband is a driver and her children are attending primary school.

loans.use: Buys dishes and clothes wholesale to add to her business inventory

loans.name: Amenodin

texts.en:
This is Amenodin P., 40, resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. He is married to Bodlia P.. They are blessed in their marriage with good health and strong physiques which enable them to work hard for their future together. They have two high-school aged children.

Amenodin operates a ready-to-wear clothing store where he also sells original DVDs, and cellular phone accessories. He mainly offers children’s clothing, summer shorts (which are very popular in tropical Philippines), statement shirts, and other basic everyday wear. This clothing is made from sheer cotton fabrics, which are all suited to the hot and humid climate. Most customers only buy made-to-order clothing when it is really necessary, as it is more expensive. Amenodin’s customers are his immediate community and neighbors.

To help him continue operations of his business, he is requesting a Php 12,000 loan. He will be utilizing the loan to buy more and varied cellular phone accessories to replenish and expand his current business inventory. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business. 
 
Amenodin dreams of being able to have a comfortable and well-off future with his family. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy more and varied cellular phone accessories

loans.name: Orliete Jose

texts.pt:
Orliete José T. nasceu na cidade de Maputo, Província de mesmo nome, sul de Moçambique, mãe de 3 filhos de 3, 7 e 11 anos de idade, o mais velho vai a Escola. Fez somente 6ª classe, não continuou devido a gravidez precoce e depois do primeiro filho não voltou a Escola. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e não sustenta ninguém para além da sua família.

Nunca saiu da sua cidade natal, é negociante ha mais de 10 anos, vende roupa nova diversa que adquire na Republica da Africa do Sul. Não possui nenhum empregado e consegue em media um rendimento de cerca de 5.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum em sua casa, mas pretende abrir uma conta bancaria para assegurar a sua economia.
 
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de vizinhas que também são clientes da instituição. Este é o seu primeiro empréstimo no valor de 10.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar peças de roupa nova diversa para aumentar quantidade do seu stock.

No futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para desenvolver ainda mais o seu negócio e adquirir um terreno para construir uma residência para os seus filhos.
texts.en:
Orliete José was born in Maputo, in the Province of same name, South of Mozambique. She is the mother of three children who are 3, 7 and 11 years old. The oldest son goes school. She only went to school until 6th grade and didn't finish due to a teenage pregnancy. She never went back to school after her first child. She lives in her own home with her family and doesn't support anyone other than them. She has never left her hometown. She has had a business selling assorted new clothing which she buys in South Africa for more than 10 years. She doesn't have any employees and has an average income of 5,000 meticais per month, which is spent in household expenses. She also manages to save some money at home but plans to open a bank account to protect her savings. She has never had loans from other banks. She became familiar with Hluvuku through neighbors who are also partners of this institution. This is her first loan, in the amount of 10,000 meticais. She intends to buy assorted new pieces of clothing to increase her inventory. She intends to request more loans in the future to further develop her business and to purchase a lot to build a house for her children.

Translated from Portuguese by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of assorted new pieces of clothing

loans.name: Tawopaneh-Iii Group

texts.en:
M’Balu K. (pictured on the left) is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Born thirty-two years ago in Makeni city, M’Balu is married and has four children.  For seven years now, M’Balu has been selling biscuits, cakes and firewood. M’Balu will use her share of the loan (SLL 500,000) to expand her business, buying firewood, biscuits, flour, cooking oil, etc.
